comment.author: 93995449@N00
comment._content: Has a Bleriot look to it.

comment.author: 7524407@N07
comment._content:
looks like a french demoiselle,  overhead wing monoplane
circa 1908

comment.author: 26881258@N07
comment._content:
No Santos-Dumont Demoiselle, the pilot was seated there beneath the wing. Also the engine is a 2 or 4-cylinder engine (no Anzani), most likely a Dutheil-Chambers which was built in a horizontal 2-cylinder version of 20 hp (air cooled).

Surely the machine superficially looks like a Blériot monoplane (Type XI) but it is not a Blériot as none of them was fitted with the mentioned horizontal engine. Further I seem to see different details in the wing (very deep) and the way the wing warping is accomplished (two pyramidal constructions above the fuselage).

Everything hints to one of the many contemporary builders who based their machine of the Blériot Type XI and made their own adjustments to 'upgrade' it. Machine on the picture could be from the USA.

comment.author: 52583849@N04
comment._content: Engine might be a Darracq (a much more common engine than the Dutheil-Chambers.) though there were a lot of one-off engines - particularly 2 cylinder ones, at that time. Prop appears to be a Chauviere, though again illegal copies were widespread - especially in the US.
